newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australian Broadcasting Corp Afternoon Update.
newsitem.headline: Australian Broadcasting Corp Afternoon Update.

text.p: RESERVE BANK DEFENDS COMMITMENT TO REDUCING UNEMPLOYMENT
The Reserve Bank Governor, Ian McFarlane, has defended the bank's commitment to reducing unemployment.
There've been industry calls for another cut in official interest rates to stimulate employment.
But Mr McFarlane has told a Parliamentary committee hearing in Sydney that the effects of three cuts in the last half of last year have yet to fully flow through.
And while inflation is at the low end of their target range, he says wage increases are still higher than they should be.
Mr McFarlane says continuing low inflation is needed to ensure long term growth.
CENTURY ZINC PROJECT ENDORSED
The Century Zinc project in Queensland's Gulf Country has been approved, more than seven years after the resource was discovered.
The Native Title Tribunal's arbitration team, sitting in Mount Isa, endorsed the agreement reached between native title claimants, the state government and the mining company.
The arbitration team heard legal argument that it no longer had the power to order whether confidential documents presented to the Tribunal this week should remain confidential.
Those documents include the project agreement itself and documents relating to a claim by some native title claimants that the state government had not acted in good faith during negotiations.
The Tribunal's Paul Seaman QC said he'd leave the questions raised today to be tested by general law.
HANSON EXPECTS MORE SUPPORT AFTER NATIONALS' BACKFLIP
The Leader of the One Nation party, Pauline Hanson, says she expects the National Party's apparent backflip on Native Title to translate into increased support for her party.
National Party Leader Tim Fischer has been forced to accept John Howard's plan after it was approved by Federal Cabinet yesterday.
Miss Hanson, speaking on ABC talkback radio in Western Queensland says she's suprised and disappointed by the National party's actions.
She says people are sick of being ignored by the government and a tremendous lot had been done for the Aboriginal race.
O'CHEE SATISFIED ON NATIVE TITLE
National Party Senator Bill O'Chee says he's now satisfied with the Prime Minister's undertakings on native title.
Senator O'Chee had threatened to quit the National Party and become an Independent, if Mr Howard's 10-point response to Wik did not include full extinguishment of native title on pastoral leases.
But Senator O'Chee told ABC Radio, Mr Howard has given the Nationals assurances on three important areas, including extinguishment.
Senator O'Chee says Queensland's previous Labor Government passed legislation stating that native title was extinguished over pastoral leases.
He says that's going to be validated in the 10-point plan as a legislative act.
STOWAWAYS' FAMILY MUCH RELIEVED
The family of the twin teenage girls found on Cape York after they'd jumped ship with a Malaysian sailor says it's much relieved the girls are heading home to New Zealand today.
Australian authorities have decided to deport the three.
The twins' brother, Andrew Ingham, says since his sisters Sarah and Joanne made front page news the family home's been under seige by the media.
The girls hade been stowed away on the ship since February, and Mr Ingham says the ordeal has been very stressful for the family.
He says everyone at home is very happy and much relieved.
PURPOSELESS ABORIGINAL CHILDREN COMMITTING SUICIDE

A professor of politics at Sydney's Macquarie University says Aboriginal children as young as ten are committing suicide - and no other society in the world is showing up incidences of suicide at such early ages.
Professor Colin Tatz has been awarded a grant to try and find ways of alleviating the problem.
He says many young Aboriginal people suffer a sense of purposelessness, with no expectations in life.
He says they want to change their lives but don't know how they can.
